description: From Latin Tantalus, from Ancient Greek Τάνταλος (Tántalos, “Tantalus”), a Phrygian king in Greek mythology who was condemned to stand in a pool of water which receded every time he tried to drink, and with overhanging branches of fruit which pulled back whenever he tried to eat.

entries.meaning: A stork of the genus Mycteria (formerly Tantalus), especially the American wood stork, Mycteria americana.
A stand in which to lock up drink decanters while keeping them visible.
examples: Yes, there was a tantalus containing brandy and whisky on the sea-chest.

entries.meaning: Something of an evasive or retreating nature, something consistently out of reach; a tantalising thing.
examples: Over all, there brooded the shadow of his injuries and the tantalus of their slow healing.
